header.title: ESOTERIC EXTENSION OF TAROT TO DEVELOP SUPERSENSORY POWERS

central_thesis: This lesson, focusing on Tarot Key 4 (The Emperor), asserts that the development of supersensory powers is intrinsically linked to understanding and integrating the masculine and feminine principles within oneself, emphasizing the development of reasoning and objective sight as foundational to intuitive and clairvoyant abilities, and ultimately to spiritual vision.

structure_content.summary: This lesson introduces Tarot Key 4, The Emperor, as representing the masculine principle, in contrast to the previous lesson's focus on The Empress (feminine principle). It highlights the Emperor's connection to Aries, the ram's head symbol, and the concept of 'sight' or vision. The text explains that the Emperor's rulership is dependent on the Empress's fertility and that both principles, though distinct, are present in all individuals. The lesson delves into the misinterpretations of masculine/feminine roles and emphasizes that reasoning (masculine) and emotion/imagination (feminine) are aspects of all people. It argues that inner balance is crucial for proper relationships and that the masculine principle, associated with reasoning, must become the inner ruler (Higher Self). The text warns against relying solely on intuition without developed reasoning, linking the order of Tarot keys to this progression. It further explores the nature of sight, distinguishing between physical sight and inner perception, and connects it to knowledge and consciousness. The lesson introduces clairvoyance as a developed faculty that requires reason for accurate interpretation, contrasting it with uncritical psychic experiences. Finally, it stresses the importance of objectivity in applying these principles, asserting that seeing reality as it is, without self-deception, leads to deeper understanding and prevents disillusionment.

key_concepts.definition: Represents the masculine principle, associated with reason, rulership, vision, and the astrological sign Aries. Symbolically depicted with a ram's head, signifying Aries.
Represents the feminine principle, associated with fertility, creativity, and maternal aspects. Her fertility is presented as essential for the Emperor's role as a ruler.

Two fundamental forces within all individuals. The masculine principle is linked to reasoning and projection (on the outer plane), while the feminine principle is linked to emotion, imagination, and receptivity (on the outer plane). On the inner plane, these polarities are reversed. Integration of both is key to personal balance and supersensory development.

The capacity to evaluate data, look at what is truly present, and avoid self-deception. Presented as a prerequisite for reliable intuition and effective supersensory perception. It is assigned to the Emperor aspect and is seen as an expression of the Higher Self.
A faculty that can only be relied upon after reasoning ability has been sufficiently developed. The text warns against mistaking unfounded hunches for true intuition.
Attributed to The Emperor, this encompasses physical sight, inner perception, and ultimately spiritual vision. It involves consciousness interpreting impressions, not just the physical act of seeing.

The ability to see things and people as they truly are, without prejudice or self-deception. Crucial for accurate perception and avoiding disillusionment. The Emperor's warrior aspect symbolizes the courage needed for objective sight.

A perception that sees beyond the surface. The lesson distinguishes between uncontrolled psychic visions and developed clairvoyance, which requires reasoning for interpretation. It is presented as a faculty that can be developed from outer faculties.
The ultimate ruler and source of reasoning capacity, representing the goal of integrating the Emperor aspect within oneself.

A harmful misconception that creates division between masculine and feminine principles. The text advocates for recognizing the interdependence and complementary nature of these principles in both men and women.

practical_system.description: The practical application of The Emperor's lesson involves cultivating the masculine principle of reason and objective sight as the internal ruler (Higher Self). This is achieved by: 1. Recognizing and integrating the masculine (reasoning) and feminine (emotional/imaginative) aspects within oneself, aiming for balance. 2. Developing strong reasoning abilities to critically evaluate data and perceive reality objectively, as intuition cannot be trusted without this foundation. 3. Practicing objectivity by seeing oneself and others without self-deception or preconceived notions, which is presented as the courageous stance of the Emperor/Aries. 4. Understanding that sight is a function of consciousness, not just the physical eyes, and that it can be developed towards spiritual vision. 5. Differentiating between unmanaged psychic experiences (which may be meaningless) and developed, reasoned supersensory perception (like clairvoyance), emphasizing that the former requires evaluation. The goal is to prepare oneself to see on 'the highest levels of your being' by extending one's range of vision and perceiving details beyond the surface.

relevant_quotes.text: The Emperor is attributed to Aries, the first sign of the Zodiac, and there are several subtle indications of this in the key. The ram's head, for instance, stands for Aries, the Ram, and the astrological sign for Aries is on the top of the Emperor's crown.
The Emperor, the ruler, the king, would have nothing to rule had not the fertility of the Empress brought forth children. The Empress' fertility is what makes him the ruler.

One important point to note about the attribution of the Emperor to the masculine principle and of the Empress to the feminine principle is that both are shown as being rulers. Esoterically, it is known that, in effect, the Empress is subject to the Emperor, to the king and ruler of the entire household.
Whether we be male or female, our reasoning capacities partake of the masculine principle and our emotional and imaginative capacities partake of the feminine principle.
The Emperor, the masculine principle in us, is assigned to the ability to reason.

The Emperor is a phase of the Fool in its aspect of rulership; for when we consider that the reasoning concept is assigned to that in us which is the ruler, we realize that the ruler must be the Higher Self.
The ability to reason must precede reliance on intuition, as shown by the order of the Tarot keys.

Sight is the sensory function attributed to this key, which also has the faculty of reason. Sight and knowledge are closely connected in our speech. When we understand something, we often say, "Oh yes, I see."

If you consider vision, you will realize that all seeing is done by the consciousness. It is your consciousness that really sees; your eyes are only an instrument, a camera lens taking in impressions and vibrations. It is the consciousness that interprets what is taken in.
The Emperor's aspect of ourselves must become the ruler, the king.

The chief problem in applying the Emperor to our own lives lies in being objective. We usually fail to be sufficiently objective because there are so many things that would frighten us if we saw them as they really are.
This seeing into his soul is no physical seeing, nor is it a psychic seeing, it is a spiritual seeing, and this is the seeing that is unbelievable until one has had this experience.

Concentrate, therefore, on all the myriad forms and conditions that surround you. Reach for the ability to see the infinite number of details that usually escape you. Thus will you prepare yourself for extending your range of vision and finally achieve the capacity to see on the highest levels of your being.

critical_analysis.relevance: This text is highly relevant to students of Western Esotericism, particularly those interested in Tarot as a symbolic system for psychological and spiritual development. It offers a structured approach to understanding the interplay of masculine and feminine principles within the self, framing it within a Tarot framework. The emphasis on reason preceding intuition aligns with many occult traditions that prioritize intellectual understanding and critical faculty before delving into more subjective or esoteric experiences. The discussion on objectivity and distinguishing between genuine spiritual sight and unmanaged psychic phenomena is particularly valuable for those navigating occult studies.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience is students of Ann Davies' teachings on Tarot and esoteric philosophy, likely those seeking to develop psychic or supersensory abilities. It is also relevant to general practitioners of occultism, particularly those interested in Tarot symbolism, Jungian archetypes, and the integration of polarities within the self. Individuals interested in developing critical thinking skills within a magical context would also find value.
